description:
NYOKA
JUNGLE PIT
By Clement Good
He paused to gaze at his work and his im.
prisoned companion with satisfaction.
"You may wonder why I didn't just put
bullet into your head," he continued, in the
manner of a criminal who must boast or burst.
"Don't think I hadn't thought of it. But a
bullet can give a killer away. I'll admit that
the chance of a ballistics expert showing up
here in the heart of the jungle is very slight.
But there's always the chance that somebody
would trace that bullet in your skull to me."
He looked at Geller as if expecting some
sign of agreement. Geller, his feet imprisoned,
his gun out of reach, was horrified by the
expression in his partner's eyes, It was mighty
close to madness, he thought.
"This method," continued Parkington, "may
be more inconvenient to you than a bullet
would be. But it leaves me in the clear. I didn't
kill you. Maybe a lion did. Maybe a cobra did.
Maybe a rhino did. Perhaps a leopard clawed
you to death. But I didn't. I'm in the clear,
NELLER and Parkington were able to walk
side by side where the path widened as
it neared the water hole. A parrot squawked
at them and they could hear the chatter of
monkeys.
"We're rich, Park! Think of it! Rich!" ex-
claimed Geller. "That collection of ivory is
worth a fortune."
"Rich!" repeated Parkington, letting his
tongue savor the word.
"It's worth a fortune and when we spłit it
we'll each have half-a-fortune," chuckled
Geller, happily.
"Uh-huh, when we split it," said Parkington.
"Step over this way, pal. I want to show you
something."
Geller followed his friend off the path,
through a tangle of vines. Suddenly the earth
seemed to give way beneath him and he gave
a startled cry as he plunged downward. His
Springfield left his hands and fell a few feet
away. The falling stopped, not suddenly but
with an oozing sensation around his feet and
legs.
It was a second or two before he fully real-
ized what had happened. He was in a pit trap
of some sort, up to his hips. Instinctively he
pushed his hands on the firm ground around
the edge of the pit to try to free himself. He
could not budge. His legs seemed held as if
in a vise.
"Hey, Park," he yelled. "Give me a hand.
I'm stuck in quicksand or something. Boy, it's
lucky you're along."
Parkington said, "Yes, I guess a man would-
n't have much chance of getting out of a
trap like that alone. I guess he'd be just about
doomed."
"He sure would," agreed Geller. "Whew!
The very idea gives me the creeps. Well, don't
stand there, Park. Get busy."
Parkington stood off and looked at his wildly
groping companion. "You fool!" he said. "Did
you ever think I would be satisfied with half
a fortune when I could have the whole thing?
I built this trap and led you into it. Clever,
isn't it?"
see?"
READS of sweat stood out on Geller's fore-
head. Parkington saw them and chuckled
maliciously. "So long, pal. The native boys
won't be looking for you. I'm going to tell
them you went off on a scouting expedition
"By the way, you were right about that
ivory. It's worth a fortune to me."
The helpless man thrashed aboút. trying
to free himself, as he heard his partner's re-
ceding footsteps. Then, realizing the futility
of such struggles, he was still. Monkeys and
birds were still chattering in the foliage all
around him. Above he could see a patch of
blue sky and flicking through it went a bird.
Geller recognized it as a vulture and shuddered
involuntarily.
From a distance came a low moaning,
hasso-profundo imoaning, that vibrated as it
swelled, then diminished and ended in sort
of an interrupted growl.
"A lion!" thought Gqller and his heart
doubled its pounding.
